if anyone is going to make optical/photonic computing work and win, it's going to be a marriage between the microLED/VCSEL array folks, and the lockin camera folks. it's not going to be using modulators from telecom folks, nor SLM/DMD from display folks. You need someone that cares about every single photon, and every single electron, and those people are doing sensing at the edge like ToF cameras starved with low power consumption.

this paper made me realize i should be looking into optoelectronic devices for sensing more. Everyone will use the same trick of optical fan-out, and MAC in time domain to reduce spatial complexity. How do you win? You win by caring about every electron you use for the modulation, and every photon for the detection. traveling-wave parametric amplifiers, how do they work, and how to tune them. i asked your beloved sota LLM "how do i tune a JTWPA? give me a step by step guide, as well as list of things i need, and list of things to be careful about", and the answer is honestly quite decent, go ahead try it yourself. what i could offer, are some refs i like, some real world examples, and hopefully also trigger some real experts to tell you what i'm wrong about. maybe i'll also talk about optical parametric amplifiers, or maybe i could convince my expert friends to talk about them instead of me..

first of all, these images are from: - Howe2025: [Kinetic Inductance Traveling Wave Parametric Amplifiers Near the Quantum Limit: Methodology and Characterization]( https://arxiv.org/abs/2507.07706) - Malnou2021: [Three-Wave Mixing Kinetic Inductance Traveling-Wave Amplifier with Near-Quantum-Limited Noise Performance]( https://doi.org/10.1103/PRXQuantum.2.010302) - [Silent Waves]( https://silent-waves.com) - Macklin2015: [A near–quantum-limited Josephson traveling-wave parametric amplifier]( https://doi.org/10.1126/science.aaa8525)

where should we start? maybe we should start with why do we need amplifiers. I once heard an anecdote from my advisor that he got into a fight at an old school microwave conference talking about measurement in a dilfridge, because people do not believe you can measure S11 of your device in a dilfridge, where you have ~60 dB or even higher attenuation on your input lines to kill the noise from room temperature. As a result, naively you'd get 120+ dB total attenuation roundtrip. luckily there is a type of component called circulators (interesting topic worth its own thread but not here), and you can use a different path out, and you can amplify the signal back so that your crappy classical electronic instruments at room temperature could detect what would otherwise be single quanta level attenuated further. In the following typical dilfridge setup, you can see a series of attenuators on the way down, the device under test (DUT), a circulator, and two amplifiers (and some isolators) on the way up. There are more amplifiers and filters after the signal gets out of the fridge, and then digitized if you are rich, or mixed down, filtered, and then digitized. The first amplifier is the most important one, since its noise will be amplified by all subsequent amplifiers. This is why there are a lot of effort into making good near-quantum-limited amplifiers, and TWPAs are some of the best ones. left image from Jiang2023: [Optically heralded microwave photon addition]( https://doi.org/10.1038/s41567-023-02129-w) [also]( https://www.osti.gov/servlets/purl/2327097) right image from ( https://x.com/jwt0625/status/1887067672007082350)

now, what is a good amplifier, and what does quantum limited amplifier mean? you also mentioned mixer, don't you feel like you should explain what a mixer is? Thankfully mixers are kind of related to amplifiers. A good amplifier is easy to define, you give me a signal, and I give you G times that signal, ideally, and G is the gain of the amplifier. The signal could have different frequencies and powers, so you'd want the amplifier to be broadband, and have high saturation power, that's a good amplifier. But there is one more thing, amplifers always add noise, so you also want the added noise to be as low as possible. Why do they always add noise? do they really have to? The answer, in principle, is actually it depends. (in practice there will always be noise added no matter what you do, tiny insertion loss on the connector? I'm sorry that is a beam splitter, and thermal noise gets added) And to answer it, some quantum jibberish is inevitable. The fastest way to arrive at the intuition, is to admit the fact that your signals are eelctromagnetic waves, and em waves follow similar rules as a simple harmonic oscillator in quantum mechanics. When you amplify the wave, you are multiplying the operators. If nothing else is added, you'll break the commutation relation of the operators, and the quantum mechanics god says, nope, you'll get at least vacuum noise added (figure 1 & 2). If an amplifier's added noise is very low single digit number of photons, people usually start calling them near quantum limited. (it's hard to say about just one amplifier, so you'll also see people talk about the system noise, and compare it to the quantum limit) Then why did i say it actually depends? That is because some amplifiers could treat different quadratures differently, and they are amplely named phase-sensitive amplifiers. One common form of them amplify one quadrature and attenuate the other one, so you'll need to know your signal for it to work well, and it will also squeeze the noise on your signal. Figure 3 shows how different kinds of noise could be visualized on top of your signal, two of them are squeezed noise (b and c). ref: Caves1982: [Quantum limits on noise in linear amplifiers]( https://painterlab.caltech.edu/wp-content/uploads/2019/06/qe_caves_limits_amplifiers.pdf) (how to quantize an em field is another interesting topic that i won't be able to do it justice here, and an over-simplified way of describing the process is: at any and every point in space-time, you can create or kill a photon, and thus you could "assemble" your em field with a sum of these photon creation operators weighted by the spatial-temporal form of your wave)

move on to mixers, and why mixers are kind of related to parametric amplifiers? marki microwave has a nice primer on mixers, and here is the first figure from it, versus one figure from Malnou2021. There are three waves involved in both cases, LO, RF, and IF for the mixer, and pump, signal, and idler for the parametric amplifier. Both processes get the name three-wave mixing because of this, and they both use the same 2nd order nonlinearity as the dominant effect. So, can you pump a mixer real hard to get amplification? Of course (if the nonlinear element is not dissipative)! Many parametric amplifiers in the 1960s are pumping a varactor, which could also work as a mixer. I'm not so familiar with these classics, so here goes the refs if you'd like to know more: Mura1966: [An ultra-low-noise 1700-Mc Parametric amplifier system]( https://ntrs.nasa.gov/api/citations/19660010467/downloads/19660010467.pdf) Decroly1973: [Parametric Amplifiers]( https://link.springer.com/book/10.1007/978-1-349-81564-7) Chpt. Technical Aspects

wait i forgot this one from PK Tien, who later went on and worked a lot on the early integrated optics stuff [1. Parametric Amplifiers]( https://nvlpubs.nist.gov/nistpubs/jres/64D/jresv64Dn6p751_A1b.pdf)

all the above measurements are done with a VNA, it's convenient and quick, but VNA is kind of horrible for characterizing nonlinear components. It's not a clean rf source, and it only looks at one frequency for the output. You really want a proper signal generator (SG), and a spectrum analyzer (SA): here is an example of various noise floors (y axis is dBm/Hz), red is the SA noise floor, green is with room T LNA on, blue is LNA + HEMT, and black is LNA + HEMT + JTWPA. I probably did not pump it hard enough, becuase you'd always want the noise floor to be dominated by the first and best amplifier (which gets amplified by all subsequent amplifiers). next is to repeat the above tuning and optimization with SG and SA. A probe of 4 GHz is used, that's the peak at the center. There are also other peaks and sidebands moving around, almost like they are welcoming you to the nonlinear world. The FSR of these sidebands are (some of) the standing wave modes of the whole JTWPA, and the FSR shrinks as the wave gets slower with higher pump power.

It's even more fun when sweeping the pump freq and looking at a wider range of the spectrum. Does this remind you of something? yeah, mode locked lasers/solitons, and you could change the pump freq and get all kinds of wacky spectrum just like some of the optical solitons. however, i did not measure any time domain proof that the sidebands are actually coherent.

lastly, some raw data of a really weak signal with TWPA off (blue) and on (yellow), look at that rising noise floor, and the sweet gain on the actual signal. If you know what the signal should be, you can convert everything to input-referred, and get a calibrated plot like the one in the 2015 JTWPA paper.

last lastly, i would like to highlight some recent development, especially on kinetic inductance based TWPA (two of the four pretty pictures in the OP), and an integrated isolator with TWPA-like nonlinear waveguide (with SNAILs). The KI based TWPA is easier to make (single layer e.g. NbTiN), and easier to operate with three-wave mixing by adding a bias current. It also has much higher P1dB, >30 higher than JTWPAs. And this isolator work is really new, not that many people are trying to solve the problem of isolators taking too much space & need to be made onto a chip, not to mention one with broad bandwidth. This one is probably annoying to operate, but exciting new way of making an on-chip isolator. Ranadive2025: [A travelling-wave parametric amplifier isolator]( https://doi.org/10.1038/s41928-025-01489-w), [arxiv]( https://arxiv.org/abs/2406.19752)

ok one more post on general background refs: - i learnt cQED by reading Dave's thesis [Circuit Quantum Electrodynamics]( https://schusterlab.stanford.edu/static/pdfs/Schuster_thesis.pdf), this is a must read. There are many more recent reviews if you prefer up to date stuff. - I really learnt how to design various circuits with JJs after Marek's thesis [Microwave photonics in superconducting circuits]( https://doi.org/10.3929/ethz-a-010735338), especially Appendix C: A shortcut to circuit quantization. (there are many reviews on design and black box quantization as well) - i flipped through refs in this review and i think you might be better off reading it instead of this thread for history developments and prior arts: Aumentado2020: [Superconducting Parametric Amplifiers: The State of the Art in Josephson Parametric Amplifiers]( https://doi.org/10.1109/MMM.2020.2993476) good luck have fun!

think thermal is just diffusion? naive! it's just a special simplified case of boltzmann transport equation. (tho diffusion should cover most of the cases, and BTE is so general it could probably describe your dating experience)
